>
>
>How would this complete list help you any more than the simple fact that the
>arrays were not of the same length?  Given that I expected them to contain
>the same number of elements, the most valuable information to me would be
>that they were of different lengths, not which elements were/were not
>present.
>
I partially don't agree.  I think that comparing vectors should tell you 
if the elements are equals.  If your testing a sort algorythm, you want 
to know if elements of the result vector are in the right position. 
 This request (assertEquals do array properly) has been expressed by 
many people and I think that it should be included in JUnit.

But I'm against the "soft warning" idea.  Don't see the added value there.

-Vladimir
subject: Re: [junit] Reporting more then 1 failed assertion per test
